msContents.summary: Petition from Dionysia to Julius Varianus, epistrategos of the Heptanomis and Arsinoite nome, enclosing a copy of a petition to Titus Flavianus Titianus, prefect of Egypt and his answer. The petition concerns the ownership of some land which Dionysia claims to have bought but which her opponent, Sarapion alleges she held only on mortgage. Both parties to the dispute were ordered to present themselves in Alexandria. Dionysia did so but Sarapion failed to appear. Dionysia, in the second petition (to the prefect Titianus) requests permission to return to her home and to have the case decided there

msItemStruct.note: Written along the fibers; on the verso, a petition
37 lines; complete except for top right corner and bottom left corner
The hand is a good-sized, fluent cursive, with occasional separation of letters
Margins are preserved on all sides except the left

There are several large holes and a break along what appears to have been a fold in the papyrus. On either side of the fold the text is damaged and along the right side of the fold the text is almost completely obliterated

provenance.p: Given to Columbia University by the Egypt Exploration Society, 1907
